content.description:
Begin in the right-facing dihedral a few feet left of the start of

Major Dude

. Ascend the dihedral as it curves right. Avoid clipping the many bolts, while remembering to protect for your second, as the route crosses

Major Dude

and

Golden Gate

. Continue right, indulging in intoxicating exposure, to the first traditionally protected opportunity to climb upward. Stagger off.
content.protection: A standard rack through three inches.
content.location:
Start a few feet left of the start of

Major Dude

. Locating “Location” before “Description” has always been bass-ackwards.

climbs.name: Uplift Mofo Party Plan
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, John Flunker, Kirk Miller, 6/27/03

content.description: Solve the first steep crux then turn on the afterburners and brachiate from huge rail-jug to rail-jug as the pump factor clock ticks.  Be ready for sustained steepness with big throws all the way to the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts to Fixe rings.
content.location:
This is the first route right of

Jolly Rancher

.

content.description:
Begin on

Dude’s Dihedral

, and merge into

Mighty Aphrodite

. Avoid clipping the many bolts along the way — good trad pro can be placed, although you could get pumped. We walked off.
content.protection: A standard rack through three inches.
content.location:
Begin as for

Dude's Dihedral

. Locating “Location” before “Description” has always been bass-ackwards.

climbs.name: Sky Chi
climbs.fa: Dave Turner, Danny Kalb, & CSU crew

content.description: This is like Tai Chi, but practiced where rock and sky meet.  I always find climbing at Dude's energizing, particularly on a sunny, crisp fall day.  It has a lot of variety in 75 feet. We climbed this after the new guidebook was published.
content.protection: 6 protection bolts; Single cams from 1/2" to #2 Camalot, a couple of medium/large stoppers.  Extra 1" cam might be helpful.  Bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is two routes right of

Dude's Jam Crack

.  Start in a left-facing corner/ramp, that has a short roof at the bottom.  A mixture of gear and bolts gets you up to and over a strenuous, bucktoothed overhang, a technical overlap, and the headwall above.

content.description:
Though quite short, this route is quite fun.  If there, I'd recommend it for the average Joe...though Josefina might find it reachy.  Move up into a small nook of sorts with underclings.  You can awkwardly reach out right to clip the 2nd bolt.  Now the fun...move right with a smidge of reach and power to just the right spot, get your feet set out right, pull up and around.  Move back left to a jug, then up and right. Clip the anchors and smile.

This may feel 5.10 for the tall dude.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location: This may the shortest route at the cliff.  It is the rightmost bolted line on the 3rd face from the left of this cliff band.

climbs.name: Red Hot Chili Peppers
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, Vaino Kodas, and Kirk Miller, 6/14/03. With direct start: John Flunker, 6/27/03

content.description: Climb a face with a crux sequence right off the ground, make a deadpoint to a sloper, hike your feet up, and get a quick shake. A few moderate moves leads to a tricky clip and another 12 b/c crux. This crux is very different than the lower one. I've heard some people start on the boulder next to the climb skipping the first crux. This route is really short anyways, so why skip the starting moves? They add whole another crux and make the route better. If you step from the boulder, it's 12b/c. If you climb directly, it is 12c.
content.protection: 5 or 6 bolts.
content.location:
This is to the left of

Green Chile

.

content.description: A lone bolt protects the start, then easy climbing leads across a blocky ledge to the route.  The crux involves a thuggish undercling combined with a high step then a big reach up and left.
content.protection: 10 bolts to rings.
content.location:
This is the bolted line left of

Howdy Doody Time

, right of

Short Dude

.

content.description: Burly, thuggish 5.11 leads to the first crux.  After pulling the tricky .12a undercling traverse, pull up onto a slab to rest up for the second .12a crux; thin, powerful moves lead to big holds to pull through the roof to the anchors.
content.protection: 12 bolts to chains.
content.location:
This is right of

Howdy Doody Time

, left of

Double Dominatrix

.

content.description:
This is a gear link-up of two sport routes.  Clip the first five bolts of

Open Space Cowboy

.  Where that route then heads right, instead pull left into a left-facing dihedral.  Stem up to an overhang, pull through, climb a short hand/finger crack, and then clip the last two bolts and anchor of

Howdy Doody Time

!
content.protection: Small standard rack, including micro cams.  7 bolts.

climbs.name: Mighty Aphrodite
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, Vaino Kodas, Dave Turner

content.description:
This is a weird, trickier-than-it-looks sport climb that feels slippery in spots with a few cruxes in its short length just left of

Short Dude

.  Move up on face moves to a thin stretch.  The first crux involves a thin left foot move.  There's a part where it's just hard to get the hands right.  Now move up under a roof.  It's a bit awkward to pull over the roof to the right, and somehow the rock gives you a bit less confidence.  Now up to the anchors...phew.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 7 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor now with Mussy hooks.
content.location:
This is the second from the right bolted line on this 3rd face from the left.  It is just left of

Short Dude

.

content.description:
This route is a link up that starts with"

Major Dude

" & finishes on "

Uplift Mofo Party Plan

".

Climb

Major Dude

past 6 bolts to just below the roof & its crux. Traverse left on a horizontal crack past a bolt in a black streak. If it feels scary to get to this bolt, then clip the 7th bolt on

Major Dude

(with a long sling).  The traverse joins

Uplift Mofo Party Plan

at its 6th bolt. This route offers a good pump on mostly big holds.
content.protection: 9-10 bolts /2 rings.
content.location:
Start on

Major Dude

.

content.description:
Major Dude was the first hard route at Dudes.

Ascend the steep face (5.9) just right of a right-facing corner to reach a stance at the base of the overhung face. Move up and left to 6th bolt. Crank over a bulge, and move up right to a jug or shelf below the lip of a small roof.  Clip the 7th bolt above the lip & execute a crux sequence using a pinch on a short arête to reach brutal hand jams.  Pull over the roof on a flared hand jam to reach a good jug on the right. Finish up overhung face moves.

F.A.: John Flunker & Mark Rolofson on July 19, 2003.
content.protection: 9 bolts / 2 Fixe rings.  Tape gloves on both hands.

climbs.name: Jolly Rancher
climbs.fa: Vaino Kodas, Mary Zuvela, Mark Rolofson, Kirk Miller

content.description: Mellow slab moves lead to steeper rock and a pumpy finish.
content.protection: 6 bolts to [2 widely-spaced Mussy hooks] and an extra bolt at the anchors to aid the change out.
content.location: Located on the West face, this is the route farthest left.

content.description:
This is the furthest right bolted line at the crag.  It ascends an arete of sorts. It has a low footsy crux with slippery hands and a higher, arm pumping crux.  It's sort of a warmup, but you may find it stiff for the 5.8 rating once given to the route.  There was a bit of grit on the route still as of June, 2010.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the furthest right of the bolted lines.

content.description:
This is an interesting route that is joined by

Dude's Way

(which was added later) to the right at its 3rd bolt.  Start up with a crux crack move or two which feel kind of physical.  Move up and right on face moves.  There are nice bulges to pass midway and near the top.  The rating posted here is that of 2 climbers who just climbed it.

Supplemental cams might be nice but are not required.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.

I'm told other climbers think this is

5.10.
content.protection: 8 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor. Consider a long draw for the 6th bolt to prevent the rope-end 'biner levering across an edge.
content.location: This starts up a right-facing dihedral with bolts to the right.  It is the left start of the 4th bolted line from the right.

content.description:
This is a nice line just to the right of

Jolly Rancher

with an interesting crux.

Once you've led

Jolly Rancher

, you can climb straight up to the rightmost bolt (of 3).  The crux seemed to be about 1/3 the way up.  At the blank bulge, you can go straight up if you are really tall, you can move to the right to abut

Uplift Mofo Party Plan

at its 2nd bolt, or you can move left abutting

Jolly Rancher

with a sidepull.  There is another off-balance move pulling up to a couple jugs.  You can get a rest sitting on the jugs.  Easier moves lead to the anchor.
content.protection:
Use the anchor bolts on

Jolly Rancher

to TR this.
content.location:
This is between

Jolly Rancher

and

Uplift Mofo Party Plan

.

climbs.name: Impeachment Day Parade
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, Kirk Miller, Stacey Carrera, 9/12/3

content.description: With two dramatic roof crux pulls, this route packs in a lot of punch.  Tricky, Elvis-like hip moves to set up for big throws help you get through the low roof.  The final roof crux demands steady body tension to a big throw out to the very lip of the final, airy roof.
content.protection:
13 bolts to rings.

Some have found rappelling instead of lowering may reduce rope twist.
content.location:
This is the route right of

Double Dominatrix

.

content.description:
Bring your full bag of tricks for this one; success will demand a bit of route finding, power, and finesse.  The movement and exposed positions are memorable to say the least.

Climb easy rock onto a ledge above the belay. From the ledge, the route climbs up and left on beautiful gold rock, traverses right into a corner, and continues up onto the arete and face above.

Say kids, what time is it?

It's Howdy Doody Time!

It's Howdy Doody Time.

It's Howdy Doody Time.

Bob Smith and Howdy Do

Say Howdy Do to you.

Let's give a rousing cheer,

Cause Howdy Doody's here,

It's time to start the show,

So kids let's go!
content.protection: 11 bolts to ring anchors.
content.location:
Near the center of the South face, left of

Open Space Cowboy

, belay near a convenient boulder seat.

content.description: The opening moves are not too difficult to clip first bolt.  The next move is left, the second clip more difficult. The crux move is up to third bolt.  Climbing past the last 2 bolts is mid- to hard-10.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus 2 anchors.
content.location:
Of the 3 total routes on North side, this route is rightmost route on North Side. If you find

Jolly Rancher

on West side, walk around left, the next route is Green Chile.

content.description: The crux is getting off the ground and moving into the first hold. The feet are shady at best, otherwise the hands are great.
content.protection: Bring a couple bouldering pads for rocks behind you.
content.location: This bouldering area is about a quarter mile hike from the furthest south-facing lead climb. The spot looks like the lead climbing area except short enough to boulder on.

content.description:
This is the right start to the 4th bolted line from the right.  This is a route where it's probably best not to have sloppy shoes for the average climber.  Crux moves right off the deck with crimping and thin foot holds challenge you.  Fortunately, you get a decent left hand sidepull.  Shortly, you gain the juggy ledge where you can mantle up. Probably best not to blow this section where the rock is in your face.  Ascend far more moderate terrain past 5 more bolts to the top.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the 4th line from the right which merges at its second bolt with

In Harmsen's Way

to its left.

climbs.name: Golden Gate
climbs.fa: Vaino Kodas, Mark Rolofson, Kirk Miller

content.description: This route offers up two fantastic sections separated by a commodius ledge.  Climb the prow with big reaches to hidden jugs, mantle, and take a nap.  When you wake up take a stab at the crux face, then into the gate.  Pulling through the roof, through the gate, and onto the ledge is like going through some kind of crazy re-birth.
content.protection: 8 bolts to ring and chain anchors.
content.location: This is located on the right edge of the West face and is characterized by its beautiful prow and the "gate", a slot through the roofs that loom overhead.

climbs.name: Dude's Jam Parade AKA The Wiessner Connect

content.description:
Start on

Dude's Jam Crack

and pull the first roof. Then right before the second roof, place cams under the flake go left to

Impeachment Day Parade's

second roof, then clip the three bolts and the anchors on

Impeachment Day Parade

.

This is a fun route to do if you have done

Dude's Jam Crack

and

Impeachment Day Parade

. It is different and fun. Be careful how you run your rope, so you don't have drag on the upper roof.
content.protection: Rack, few long slings, 5 quickdraws. It is good to have couple long draws for the roof to prevent rope drag.  I placed two number 4s under the flake.
content.location:
This starts on

Dude's Jam Crack

and finishes on

Impeachment Day Parade

.

content.description: This splendid crack climb would be at right home at Cookie Cliff, or any other granite crack climber's crucible.  It is well-protected throughout.
content.protection: Standard rack, up to a #3 Camalot.  An RP is helpful up higher in the "changing corner" section.  There is no fixed anchor on top, although before the final 15 feet, it is possible to lean over and clip the bolt anchor for the route to the left.  If you intend to build your own anchor on top, a couple of extra medium pieces will come in handy.
content.location: Dude's Jam Crack is one of the more obvious landmarks on the proud south face. It is straight and tall, from bottom to top, in the center-right of the face.  If you climb to the top, walking off the back is easy.

climbs.name: Dude's Five Nine
climbs.fa: Kirk Miller, Mark Rolofson, Vaino Kodas, Mary Zuvela

content.description:
This is a decent line, probably easier than

Jugs Out For The Lads

that ascends the 3rd from the right bolted line.  There is an interesting crux move around the 2nd bolt which can be done to the right with a foot on the mini-arete or more directly with a mantle of sorts.  Continue up fun, ledgy, more moderate terrain.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the 3rd bolted line in from the right.

FWIW, the name of the route suggests it does not start with the 11- start.

content.description:
The crux is between the 4th and 5th bolts, climbing over first minor roof.

The guide locates the Dude's Dihedral route left of

Mighty Aphrodite

.
content.protection: 8 bolts, 2 anchors, QDs.
content.location:
It is the next route immediately left of

Mighty Aphrodite

.

content.description: This route starts in the bottom of the overhanging rock. The start is a hand jam with your left hand while your right hand is in the lowest crack. You reach out with your right hand to an awesome hold to your right. Release your left hand, work it up the left side till you feel a pretty solid crimp, and match with your right. There are two jugs up top for the finish. Top out to finish.
content.protection: For protection, bring two bouldering pads: one to put inside the small cave and one to cover the rock right outside the entrance.
content.location:
This is located in between

Double Dominatrix

and

Dude's Abs

.

content.description: Dude's Abs is a slab route that starts in the middle of the boudler, moves to the left edge of the boulder, and works its way up and across to reach a topout. The route starts with two perfect crimps. It requires a match on the undercling to the left of the start. The crux is a massive static left hand to the sloper at the far left. The rest of the problem is simple slab. Caution, the route is directly over a series of smaller boulders. I highly recommend a spotter for this one.
content.protection: Crashpads and a spotter. I recommend multiple pads as the route stretches across the boulder.
content.location:
The route is located between

Double Dominatrix

and the

Impeachment Day Parade

on Dude's Throne South face. The route start is located near the center of the boulder. You can get down a number of ways. 1. After sending, walk towards

Impeachment Day Parade

. There is an easy climb around to the ground. 2. Slide on your butt toward

Double Dominatrix

, and find nice feet. There is an overhang you need to catch with both hands, and work your feet down.

content.description:
This a probably my favorite route at Dude's Throne and the one I was most drawn to establish.

I have redpointed it 13 times as of 2010. Scramble up to a ledge & clip 1st bolt.  Move up right on easy terrain to 2nd bolt.  The first 5.12 crux ascends a vertical edge via lieback moves.  Enter a right-facing, right-leaning dihedral that is followed to a double set of roofs.  The second 5.12 crux uses small holds to reach jugs over the roofs.  The third 5.12 crux uses small holds to get stood over the roof on the jugs. Continue up a steep face to a small 5.11 bulge that leads to a good ledge. Move right a few feet on the ledge & rest up!  Finish up a bulging .12a face, moving up left past the last 2 bolts.
content.protection: 12 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor. The 5th, 6th, and 7th bolt have had fixed chain draws with 3/8" quicklinks and carabiners, since the FA. For easy cleaning of the bottom four draws, clip the climber's end of the rope through each fixed draw when lowering.
content.location: This ascends the center of the south face.

content.description: Clip the first two blots using the large block on the left. We used the horn and finger crack on the left to jog right and then fired straight up. This seemed obvious, but it was not 5.11+ climbing. Alternatively, a hard move lurks between clips 1 and 2 that might yield a straight up line at the harder grade. There is a nice move passing third clip. This has terrrific rock, but it is way too short.
content.protection: Four quickdraws and something for the double chains at the top.
content.location: It is the furthest left in this sector.

content.description:
There is clean, solid rock all the way on this one. Buster Brown is an elegant technical route.

Moderate climbing starts up a fun tight hands crack, over a pillar, and through a small roof. From the jugs above the roof begin the hard climbing by breaking hard right to a left-angling flake/dike and follow it to another small rooflet with underclings. From here, gain a finger crack and follow it to a large flake and jugs out left. Finish with easy climbing to the anchor. This is a pretty sustained route with no distinct crux.
content.protection: 12 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This route begins up a tight hands crack to the right of

Dude's Jam Crack

. The top half of the route has a distinct brown streak.

content.description:
Start 15 feet right  of "

Golden Gate

". Climb a vertical face up a short arête past 2 bolts to a roof. Step left & clip the 3rd bolt under the roof's lip. Pull over the roof (.12a) along a short, left-facing corner past the 4th bolt.  Take a good rest above the roof on a 1" wide foothold. Make a blind reach over a small roof to clip the 6th bolt that protect the crux.  Traverse right around the roof to a sharp sidepull. Reach poor crimpers, & dyno to an undercling.  A strange move off the undercling reaches a sloping shelf. A final hard section, past the 8th bolt gains jug. Stroll to the anchor.

Long slings are recommended on the first 2 bolts to reduce rope drag.  I clip the 2nd bolt with a short quickdraw & a long sling on the same biner into the bolt hanger.  Once I've clipped 3rd bolt, I reach down and unclip from the short quickdraw on the 2nd bolt.  A long draw is nice on the 7th bolt, because clipping off the undercling is dicey.  This route has a wild crux sequence.
content.protection: 9 bolts and 2 rings anchor.
content.location:
It is located on the left side of the south face 15 feet right of "

Golden Gate

".

content.description:
This is the second bolted line from the right.  It has an easy start with a reachy crux at the 4th bolt.  Taller climbers may find it easier since it may be climbed more directly, whereas short climbers may find it harder, since you have to do more intermediate moves to the right.  It is nice in that you can back down to a good rest if you have to go up and figure out the sequence.

For more details, check out Mark's new guide...fading memory is not as good.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the second bolted climb from the right.
